DetailContent.body: Signs and symptoms include: expiratory wheeze, prolonged expiration, increased inflation pressures, desaturation, hypercapnia, upsloping capnograph trace, silent chest. Can occur alone or as part of another problem.
START
Call for help and inform theatre team of problem
Give 100% oxygen
Stop surgery / other stimulation

Fully expose the chest and perform a rapid systematic examination:

  • Inspect, percuss, palpate, auscultate.
  • Absence of wheeze may indicate severe bronchospasm with no air movement.

Deepen anaesthesia:

  • Inhalational anaesthetic agents are bronchodilators AND bronchospasm may be a consequence of light anaesthesia.
  • Avoid isoflurane or desflurane if possible – airway irritant if increased rapidly.

Exclude conditions that may be misinterpreted as bronchospasm:

  • Mispositioned or occluded airway device.
  • Endobronchial or oesophageal intubation.
  • Occlusion of breathing system - check all hoses.
  • Consider other conditions mimicking bronchospasm (Box A).

DetailContent.head: Box A: ALTERNATES and MIMICS
DetailContent.body:
Wheeze: pulmonary oedema; ARDS; laryngospasm.

Raised airway pressure: obstruction of larynx, trachea or bronchi; decreased lung compliance; pneumothorax.
Consider anaphylaxis; if suspected →3-1

Treat bronchospasm (Box B). First line is salbutamol by metered dose inhaler or by nebuliser (remove HME filter or nebulise downstream); intraVENOUS route is second line. Other drugs at clinician discretion.

DetailContent.head: Box B: SALBUTAMOL
DetailContent.body:
Salbutamol

  • Nebuliser:
    Child <5 yr, 2.5 mg
    Adult and >5 yr 5 mg
    (Remove HME filter OR nebulise downstream)
  • IntraVENOUS bolus:
    Adult 250 µg diluted, slowly
    Child 1-23 months 5 µg.kg⁻¹ once over 5 mins
    Child 2-17 years 15 µg.kg⁻¹ once over 5 mins (max. 250 µg)
  • Adult intraVENOUS infusion:
    5-20 µg.min⁻¹
  • Child intraVENOUS infusion:
    0.5-1 µg.kg⁻¹.min⁻¹ (max. 20 µg.min⁻¹)

DetailContent.head: Box B: IPRATROPIUM
DetailContent.body:
Ipratropium

  • Nebuliser:
    2-12 yr 0.25 mg
    Adult 0.5 mg

DetailContent.head: Box B: ADRENALINE
DetailContent.body:
Adrenaline

  • Nebuliser:
    Child 0.5 ml of 1:1000
    Adult 5 ml of 1:1000
  • IntraMUSCULAR:
    <6 mo 50 µg
    <6 yr 120 µg
    <12 yr 250 µg
    Adult 500 µg
  • Slow intraVENOUS bolus:
    0.1 - 1 µg.kg⁻¹ (Adult 10-100 µg)

DetailContent.head: Box B: OTHER DRUG DOSES
DetailContent.body:
• Magnesium
    IntraVENOUS over 20 mins: 50 mg.kg⁻¹ (Adult 2 g)
  • Ketamine
    IntraVENOUS bolus: Adult 20mg
    IntraVENOUS infusion: 1-3 mg.kg⁻¹.hr⁻¹
  • Aminophylline
    IntraVENOUS over 20 mins: 5 mg.kg⁻¹ (omit if already on theophylline)
    IntraVENOUS infusion:
    <9 yr 1 mg.kg⁻¹.hr⁻¹
    <16 yr 0.8 mg.kg⁻¹.h⁻¹
    Adult 0.5 mg.kg⁻¹.h⁻¹
  • Hydrocortisone:
    IntraVENOUS: 4 mg.kg⁻¹ (Adult 200 mg)
If airway soiling/aspiration suspected airway see Box C

DetailContent.head: Box C: ACTIONS IF AIRWAY SOILING/ASPIRATION
DetailContent.body:
Consider tracheal intubation and tracheal toilet

Use nasogastric tube to aspirate gastric contents
Use appropriate ventilation strategy (Box D)

DetailContent.head: Box D: VENTILATION STRATEGIES
DetailContent.body:
Increase expiratory time to allow complete expiration

Pressure control ventilation may be better

Be alert to ‘breath stacking’

Permissive hypercapnia may be appropriate
If raised airway pressure and/or desaturation persists, consider →2-2 (Hypoxia/desaturation/cyanosis)
Obtain a chest X-ray as soon as clinically safe to do so
Plan appropriate placement for post-procedure care
